comments.content: I think you are right. The questions is asking for "tools" <plural>, so this may be multiple choice.

discussion.content: The second is a fuzzer. You can use the burp suite to fuzz the get request. Definitely think this is a 2 parter though. Port scanner and fuzzer
Shouldn't this question have more than one answer?
The first tool is a port scanner. The second could be a HTTP interceptor. I'm not sure which of the tool is the question asking for. I dont think its a fuzzer.

comments.content: Based on the output after the “TOKEN” parameter. If you use a utility such as WFUZZ, it can produce this output depending on the file you are using to perform the FUZZ.

questions.question_text:
A consulting firm was hired to conduct assessment for a company. During the first stage, a penetration tester used a tool that provided the following output:

TCP 80 open -

TCP 443 open -

TCP 1434 filtered -
The penetration tester then used a different tool to make the following requests:
GET / script/login.php?token=45$MHT000MND876
GET / script/login.php?token=@#984DCSPQ%091DF
Which of the following tools did the penetration tester use?

comments.content:
From the question: "Company A has shown an aversion to even minimal amounts of risk acceptance."
I think this is CompTIA's way of telling us "accepting the risk" is out.

discussion.content:
When to accept risks?
We choose the strategy of risk acceptance when it turns out to be the most economical option to do nothing about it. That is to say that the risk is either so small or so unlikely that we decide to cope with the consequences in case the incident happens.

comments.content:
From the question: the risk "would be expensive to guard against." I think CompTIA is telling to tell you that mitigation is out. 
The question gives no indication as to whether or not transfer would be affordable. But, by process of elimination, transfer may be the best answer

discussion.content: Answer: B, Mitigate - rationale from my optic - the question asked is worded from the perspective of the engineer, "should the engineer recommend..." Assuming he/she's the one that is proposing the ICS integration, why would the engineer recommend avoidance? That would not be complimentary to his/her proposal?

DEFINITELY A
This question is poorly worded but it doesn't really matter:
The answers are LITERALLY in the order that they should be recommended, regardless of a company's aversion to risk.
A. Avoid -- you ALWAYS attempt to avoid risk first.
B. Mitigate -- when you can't avoid risk (e.g. purchasing a better platform or closing a small vulnerability) you add additional controls to mitigate the risk
C. Transfer -- if it is implausible or unfeasible to avoid or mitigate the risk appropriately, you can transfer it to a third party if you have the $$$
D. Accept -- if you are unable to avoid, mitigate, or fund a transfer of risk, all that's left to do is either accept the risk or stop using whatever is introducing risk into your environment (but this would also be AVOIDing the risk, so probably not an option if you've made it all the way to D).

comments.content: From the question: "A security engineer is preparing recommendations regarding the risk of a PROPOSED introducing legacy ICS equipment." -- the decision hasn't been made, this is the planning phase. The engineer should avoid the risk by finding non-legacy ICS equipment that introduces no risk into the environment.

I don’t think this can be A because it sounds like the decision was already made to go with the legacy ICS. That would lead me to think our best option would be to mitigate the risk next. But the wording if the question is too poor for me to feel confident

I agree. The company is against even the smallest hint of risk. The security engineer is only proposing this project, so it's not in place. Due to the history of company A's posture towards risk, you can only assume they will Avoid it all together.
Why would the engineer propose the system, if the engineer felt the company should avoid risk by not getting the system?

From the question: "A security engineer is preparing recommendations ..."
If the engineer is recommending the system, does it make sense that the engineer - at the same time - recommend against getting the system? "I recommend we get this system, but to avoid risk we should not get this system."
Oops. I meant "the engineer is *not* recommending the system."

On second thought, the engineer is recommending the system. The engineer is recommending to what to do about the risks associated with system. Accepting is out because the company will not accept any risk. Mitigating and transferring are out because the vulnerability is expensive to guard against. By process of elimination, the only alternative to avoid the system

"you ALWAYS attempt to avoid risk first."
Is that really true? Everything has some risk.
This is so not true* - sorry typo.

OMG! This is so not sure, please re-read the first 4 chapters regarding the risk management. Avoiding risk means not implementing solution at all, "Risk avoidance is a mechanism where the enterprise avoids a particular threat. It can do this through the action that avoid exposure, such as removing a feature that increases the exposure" and, "this method cannot be employed against all threats" and "All business activity involves a level of risk." etc etc. Page 100, A-I-O by Lane.

discussion.content: The question seems to imply that risk acceptance is out - because the company will not accept risks. And risk mitigation is out - because it's too expensive. Maybe the company should simply avoid the risk by rejecting the legacy ICS system, and getting something else? Or should the company transfer the risk?

comments.content: I was thinking Accept also, but as mentioned above - the company is risk intolerant. Mitigation it is.

Without knowing if other ICS systems are available, or the costs of such systems if they are available; and without knowing if the the risk can be transferred, or what that would cost; there seems to be no objective way to answer this question.
Probably, the first recommendation should be to reject the legacy ICS system.

discussion.content: Accept? The question is very poorly worded. But it seems like the question is saying that the risk is trivial, and the cost of guarding against the risk is expensive.

questions.question_text:
In the past, the risk committee at Company A has shown an aversion to even minimal amounts of risk acceptance. A security engineer is preparing recommendations regarding the risk of a proposed introducing legacy ICS equipment. The project will introduce a minor vulnerability into the enterprise. This vulnerability does not significantly expose the enterprise to risk and would be expensive against.
Which of the following strategies should the engineer recommended be approved FIRST?

A company has adopted and established a continuous-monitoring capability, which has proven to be effective in vulnerability management, diagnostics, and mitigation. The company wants to increase the likelihood that it is able to discover and therefore respond to emerging threats earlier in the life cycle.
Which of the following methodologies would BEST help the company to meet this objective? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Form and deploy a hunt team.
choices.E: Use a protocol analyzer with appropriate connectors.

discussion.content:
Please move the answers to the solutions tab and remove them from the end of answer D
Thank you.

comments.content: Yes, seriously, makes it very hard to try to guess beforehand. Very frustrating!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Going with C. Form and deploy a hunt team and D. Institute heuristic anomaly detection.

I thought maybe A (an IPS) could have been the answer, but the AIO book (p. 429) has hunt teaming and heuristic analytics under incident detection which, to me, detection (not necessarily prevention) fits "discovery" better. IPS can be signature based, which may not help with "emerging threats." But heuristics "intelligently gathers data points from various host and network data sources within a specific environment" which would better aid in "discovery."

This question isn't asking about prevention, but discovery.
i assume an IPS is already part of their infrastructure based on the wording of the Q

Maybe: BC ?
In this question, the objective is to: "discover and therefore respond to emerging threats earlier in the life cycle." Not to install controls against those threats. At they point, they are just trying to find what threats are out there, so they can decide what controls are needed.

comments.content:
CD seems to be the given answer now. 
I think a "hunt team" makes more sense than an IDS. They are already continuously monitoring. Hunt teams work to detect, identify, and understand an advanced and determined threat agent. Hunt teams seek the human origins of attacks and focus their attention on disruption or removal of those threat agents, instead of the attacks themselves. Hunt teams would clearly meet the objectives stated in the question.

AD, the given answer is correct
Heuristic anomaly detection is the fastest way to discover threats and by combining it with IPS you can respond to those threats in near-real-time. The downside is you get a lot of false positives and it can impact users, but that's not a consideration in this question.

choices.F: Perform an IOC sweep to determine the impact.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AF
A & F.
Incident Response Steps: Prepare, identify/detect, contain... Security analyst has detected the issue, now it's containment time. Hence, A.
EDR can run a sweep/query based on IOCs, hash values, etc - Hence F.
Why not B - legal hold is sent to an organization by its legal department to not erase certain info because of ongoing legal case or the one that is imminent. Neither of the two are described in this scenario nor would the security analyst know about it, this is more of a cybersec or infosec director's place, at least where I've worked.

Selected Answer: AF
A. Contain the server.
F. Perform an IOC sweep to determine the impact.

comments.content: I am not seeing where any legalities are involved.

discussion.content: Other sources say B: Legal hold, but A feels right to me.

Also, Two of the link choices used HTTP and not HTTPS as shown when hovering over the links as shown:

Since we need to do this in the most secure manner possible, they should not be used.
Finally, the second link was used and the MD5 utility of MD5sum should be used on the install.exe file as shown. Make sure that the hash matches.

Finally, type in install.exe to install it and make sure there are no signature verification errors.
